feed.title: Google Cloud: Cloud SQL for MySQL
feed.subtitle: Changelog for Google Cloud product: Cloud SQL for MySQL

entry.content:
The release note on August 13, 2025 regarding Private Service Connect (PSC) outbound connectivity has been updated.

PSC outbound connectivity is required for homogeneous migrations to PSC-enabled Cloud SQL instances using Database Migration Service. For more information, see PSC outbound connections.
entry.summary: The release notes for Private Service Connect (PSC) outbound connectivity have been updated as of August 13, 2025. This update is relevant for homogeneous migrations to PSC-enabled Cloud SQL instances utilizing the Database Migration Service.
entry.title: Changed: Private Service Connect Outbound Connectivity Updated

entry.content:
Cloud SQL Managed Connection Pooling is now generally available (GA). Managed Connection Pooling lets you scale your workloads by optimizing resource utilization for Cloud SQL instances using pooling.

For more information, see Managed Connection Pooling overview.
entry.summary: Cloud SQL Managed Connection Pooling is now GA. This feature helps optimize resource utilization for Cloud SQL instances through pooling, enabling better workload scalability.
entry.title: Feature: Cloud SQL Managed Connection Pooling Now Generally Available

entry.content:
You can now enable your instance to take a final backup at instance deletion and define its retention period by setting the final backup instance setting.

You can also create a custom organization policy to define final backup instance settings. For more information, see Final backup.
entry.summary: You can now enable your instance to take a final backup at instance deletion and define its retention period by setting the final backup instance setting.
entry.title: Feature: Instance backup on deletion

entry.content: You can save and manage SQL queries in Cloud SQL Studio. This feature is in Preview. For more information, see Saved queries overview.
entry.summary: Save and manage SQL queries in Cloud SQL Studio.
entry.title: Feature: Cloud SQL Studio Feature

entry.content: Now you can use Private Service Connect backends, as an alternative to Private Service Connect endpoints, to access Cloud SQL instances.
entry.summary: Private Service Connect backends are now available as an alternative to endpoints for Cloud SQL instance access.
entry.title: Feature: New Private Service Connect Option for Cloud SQL

entry.content: Now you can create an IPv6 endpoint for Private Service Connect (PSC) connections. For more information, see Connect to an instance using Private Service Connect.
entry.summary: Create an IPv6 endpoint for Private Service Connect connections.
entry.title: Feature: IPv6 Endpoint for PSC

entry.content: You can no longer set a deny maintenance period for instances that are running a maintenance version older than 12 months. To update your instance, perform self-service maintenance or wait until the next maintenance window to update your instance automatically. For more information about maintenance, see Maintenance updates on Cloud SQL instances.
entry.summary: Deny maintenance periods are no longer available for instances with older maintenance versions.
entry.title: Deprecated: Maintenance Update

entry.content: Cloud SQL now supports Private Service Connect (PSC) outbound connectivity. With PSC outbound connectivity, you can attach a PSC interface to your existing Cloud SQL PSC-enabled instances to allow your instances to make outbound connections to your network. This is required for homogeneous migrations to PSC-enabled Cloud SQL instances using Database Migration Service. For more information, see PSC outbound connections.
entry.summary: Cloud SQL now supports Private Service Connect (PSC) outbound connectivity, enabling instances to connect to your network. This feature is essential for homogeneous migrations to PSC-enabled Cloud SQL instances using Database Migration Service.
entry.title: Feature: Private Service Connect for Cloud SQL

entry.content: Cloud SQL for Enterprise Plus edition supports quality enhancements for AI-assisted troubleshooting. With AI-assisted troubleshooting, you can resolve complex database performance issues like slow queries and high load for your instances in a guided manner. To use AI-assisted troubleshooting, you need Gemini Cloud Assist and query insights for Enterprise Plus edition.
entry.summary: AI-assisted troubleshooting for Cloud SQL Enterprise Plus.
entry.title: Changed: Cloud SQL Updates

entry.content:
Cloud SQL for MySQL now supports model endpoint management to help you build your generative AI applications. With model endpoint management, you can register and call remote AI model providers or access the Vertex AI integration. This feature is in Preview and available in Cloud SQL for MySQL version 8.0.36 and later, which includes Cloud SQL for MySQL version 8.4.

To use model endpoint management, update your instance to [MySQL version].R20250531.01_14 or later, and make sure that you've enabled the integration with Vertex AI on your instance. You can perform self-service maintenance or wait until the next maintenance window to update the maintenance version of your instance automatically.
entry.summary: Cloud SQL for MySQL now supports model endpoint management, allowing you to build generative AI applications by registering and calling remote AI model providers or accessing Vertex AI integration. This feature is available for MySQL version 8.0.36 and later.
entry.title: Feature: New Feature: Model Endpoint Management in Cloud SQL for MySQL

entry.content:
Cloud SQL now offers two options of backup services to manage your instance's backups:

  • Enhanced backups (Preview): backups are managed and stored in a centralized backup management project that leverages the Backup and DR service, and provides enforced retention, granular scheduling, and longer retention.
  • Standard backups (existing option): backups are created, managed, and stored in the same project as your Cloud SQL instances.

You can choose between these options based on your instance's requirements and needs. Although instances can't use both backup options at the same time, Cloud SQL gives you the ability to switch between these backup options as necessary.

For more information about the available options and their limitations, see Backup options.
entry.summary: Cloud SQL introduces enhanced backups with centralized management and longer retention, alongside standard backups. You can switch between options as needed.
entry.title: Feature: Cloud SQL Backup Options

entry.content:
The write endpoint feature for Cloud SQL Enterprise Plus edition instances is now generally available (GA). This endpoint is a global domain name service (DNS) name and resolves to the IP address of the current primary Cloud SQL instance that's enabled with private services access.

By using a write endpoint, you can avoid having to make application connection changes after performing a switchover or replica failover operation to test or mitigate a region failure.

For more information, see Connect to an instance using a write endpoint.
entry.summary: The Cloud SQL write endpoint for Enterprise Plus edition instances is now generally available. This feature provides a stable global domain name, resolving to the primary instance
entry.title: Feature: Cloud SQL write endpoint now available

entry.content: You no longer have to upgrade your instance to MySQL 8.0.37 before you upgrade to Cloud SQL for MySQL 8.4. You can upgrade to Cloud SQL for MySQL 8.4 from any minor version of Cloud SQL for MySQL 8.0. For more information about upgrading the major version of a Cloud SQL instance, see Upgrade the database major version-place.
entry.summary: You can now upgrade to Cloud SQL for MySQL 8.4 from any minor version of MySQL 8.0, removing the previous requirement to upgrade to 8.0.37 first. For more details on major version upgrades, refer to the documentation.
entry.title: Changed: Cloud SQL for MySQL 8.4 upgrade flexibility
